div.p: The main page displays the records, which are listed in chronological order. They are listed under the following categories: a serial number, a title describing their content, the name of the pretorian prefect(s) featured in the inscription, the occurrence of the inscription in the Prosopography of the Later Roman Empire, the emperor(s) in power at the time the inscription was made, and the dating of the inscription.
From the main page you can access the specific record by pressing the number in the column on the left (N. PPRET).
Each record is organized into 4 sections:
A) IDENTIFYING SECTION OF THE RECORD AND PREFECT(S)
1st panel: includes the number and title of the record, a list of text editions with links to online editions, the name of the praetorian prefect(s) in the record, and the date of the record.
B) THE INSCRIPTION - MATERIAL STRUCTURE
2nd panel: Provenance and location of the inscription (ancient and modern context).

3rd panel: Type of support (e.g. statue base or stone slab), material of the support, possible re-use, dimensions of the support, dimensions of the letters, epigraphic field, writing technique, language, rhythm, and paleography.
4th panel: Inscription category.
C) THE INSCRIPTION – TEXT
5th panel: Latin or Greek text of the inscription, with critical apparatus.
6th panel: Translations of the inscription into English, French, and Italian.

7th panel: Critical commentary with updates on the inscription and on the praetorian prefects in all their aspects (e.g. ancillary epigraphic evidence, as a Latin or Greek text, as a textual category and as a monument type, as a profile of the praetorian prefect(s) and of other personas, discussion on the chronological aspects, career, relations with sovereigns, specific contents, etc.).
8th panel: Bibliography cited in the record.
D) EPIGRAPHY AND THE PRAETORIAN PREFECTS
9th panel: Relations between text, inscription typology, the praetorian prefect(s) (awarders/recipients/cited), their title, their mandate, their competences, and their career.
The search page is organized into two vertical columns.
The column on the left houses the following sections:

list.item: - Text search: this section allows textual searches of the complete PPRET Inscriptions database (including translations, commentaries, etc.), or searches of the texts of inscriptions only.
- Date: this section allows you to search PPRET Inscriptions records within chronological ranges.

- Filters: this section allows you to search PPRET Inscriptions records by the identifying section of the inscription and the praetorian prefect, the material structure of the inscription and its ancient and modern location, or the correlation between the inscription and the mentioned praetorian prefects.

div.p: Filters can be combined with parameters selected in the other sections to further refine searches.

The Results column on the right shows the list of records found via the search; to see the individual record, you need to select it in this column. In the ‘Search page’, if no filter has been selected yet, the list includes all the PPRET Inscriptions records in numerical/chronological order.

If you want to perform a specific textual search (both in the ancient texts and in the other parts of the editions, namely the metadata, translations, commentary, and bibliography), you can type your text in the ‘Text search’ box in the ‘Search’ page and then press ‘Enter’. PPRET Inscriptions records mentioning the word(s) you searched for (ancient name, modern author, place, source, date, etc.) will be listed as results in the column on the right. Text searches are not case-sensitive.

If you select the option 'Search only in the inscription text' you will restrict the search to the Latin or Greek text of the inscriptions. The search ignores epigraphic conventions (such as round and square brackets).
You can use the * wildcard to search for segments of words: for example, a search for nobilita* will return nobilitas, nobilitatis, nobilitate, and so on.

If the search includes several consecutive words, you should surround them with double quotation marks (" "): for example, to search for viro followed by clarissimo, you should type "viro clarissimo". Attention: when you perform a precise search for a sequence of several words, you cannot use the wildcard *.

If the search includes several non-consecutive words, you should type the boolean search AND between the words you want to search (which in this case must not be in the double quotation marks " "), so that the list of results will include the records in which all the words typed are cited: for example, typing viro AND clarissimo you will get a list of records in which both terms appear. By typing viro clarissimo (or viro OR clarissimo) you will get a list of records where at least one of the searched words appears.

To type Greek text you can use the virtual keyboard that appears under the search box by pressing 'Greek keyboard'. In the lower right corner of the keyboard you will also find the wildcard *, double quotation marks " and the Delete key ⇐. To hide the keyboard, you have to press 'Greek keyboard' again.
To reset your search, press 'Reset search'.

Attention: The following sections 'Date' and 'Filters' allow you to set several search filters, which affect the text search. If one or more filters from these sections are selected and active, 'Current filters' appears above the 'Filters' section. If you want to remove specific search filters that you have selected, click on the 'x' to the right of the corresponding filter in the 'Current filters' section.

To select the PPRET records within a short or long chronological range from 284 to 450 AD (from one year to 156 years) move the cursors on the left and right sides of the horizontal bar. In the right column will appear the list of the records included in the selected chronological period.
This section allows you to set parameters in several categories. To view the list of all possible values for each filter, press the filter name; to hide it, press the filter name a second time.
The column on the right shows the list of the results of the search.
ONOMASTICS OF THE MENTIONED PRAETORIAN PREFECTS

Prefect name: by selecting this, you will get an alphabetical list of all the Praetorian Prefect 'holders' of a PPRET Inscriptions record. The number within brackets shows how many records each prefect has.
Prefect gentilicium: by selecting this, you will get the alphabetical list of all the gentilicia of the praetorian prefect 'holders' of a PPRET Inscriptions record.
Prefect cognomen: by selecting this, you will get the alphabetical list of all cognomina of the praetorian prefect 'holders' of a PPRET Inscriptions record.
Prefect signum: by selecting this, you will get the alphabetical list of all the signa of the praetorian prefect 'holders' of a PPRET Inscriptions record.
EDITIONS

Edition: by selecting this, you will get the full alphabetically ordered list of abbreviations of corpora, syllogies, journals, or the alphabetically ordered author's last name for monographs and papers containing an edition or a re-edition of an inscription published in PPRET Inscriptions. The list is a comprehensive list of all the editions of inscriptions examined in the database.

PLRE: by selecting this, you will get access to three entries: NEW denotes inscriptions unknown to PLRE I (1971); PLRE I denotes inscriptions already lemmatized in PLRE I; REV denotes inscriptions known to PLRE I, but substantially re-examined or revised.
CHRONOLOGY
Emperors and their prefects: by selecting specific time frames, you will get a list of inscriptions pertaining to the corresponding time frame, which matches the years of the following reigns:

list.item: 2. The Crisis of the Tetrarchy (306-312 AD)
7. Valentinian I and Valens AA. (364-378 AD)
8. Gratian, Valentinian II, Theodosius I <Maximus, Eugenius> AAA. (379-395 AD)

div.p: You will find the number of PPRET inscriptions included in each time frame between brackets.

Dated inscriptions: by selecting a date, you will see the PPRET Inscriptions records dated to that specific year. You will find the number of PPRET Inscriptions records dated to that year between brackets.
LOCATION
Findspot: by selecting this, you will get the list of places in which the inscriptions were found.
Ancient city: by selecting this, you will get a list of ancient places from where the inscriptions originally came.
Modern city: by selecting this, you will get a list of modern places from which the inscriptions come.

Province: by selecting this, you will get the list of the provinces from which the inscriptions come. The term ' Urbs ' is a convention to denote the urban area under the control of the prefect of Rome.
Diocese: by selecting this, you will get a list of the civil dioceses from which the inscriptions come.
Regional prefecture: by selecting this, you will get a list of the regional praetorian prefectures from which the inscriptions come.
Ancient location: by selecting this, you will get a list of public or private space typologies in which the inscription was originally located.
Current location: by selecting this, you will get a list of modern locations in which the inscription is currently located.
SUPPORT AND TEXT
Text category: by selecting this, you will get a list of the inscription categories.
Monument type: by selecting this, you will get the list of inscribed monument types.
Material: by selecting this, you will get the list of material types of the monument.
Technique: by selecting this, you will get the list of epigraphic writing techniques.
Epigraphic field preservation: by selecting this, you can get the list of the preservation status of the epigraphic field.

Inscribed field reuse: by selecting this, you will get the list of inscribed field re-use types, i.e., non-re-used fields (No), re-used fields (Yes), or inscriptions for which there is no certain information about the inscribed field re-use.

Monument reuse: by selecting this, you will get the list of options concerning the monument re-use, i.e., non-re-used support (No), re-used support (Yes), or inscriptions for which there is no certain information about the support re-use.

Opistographic: by selecting this, you will get the list of options concerning how many sides of the monument have been inscribed, i.e., inscriptions inscribed on two sides of the support (Yes), inscriptions inscribed on one side only (No), or inscriptions for which there is no certain information about the inscribed sides.

Palaeography: by selecting this, you will get the list of styles of epigraphical writing. For the sake of simplicity, these have been narrowed down to four categories: monumental capital, rustic capital, uncial, and inscriptions for which there is no certain information about the style of the epigraphical writing.
Language: by selecting this, you will get the list of inscriptions in Latin or in Greek.
Rhythm: by selecting this, you will get the list of inscriptions in prose or in poetry.
INSCRIPTIONS AND PRAETORIAN PREFECTS

Number of praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you can sort the inscriptions mentioning the name of only one, multiple, or all the praetorian prefects in office, and how they are related to the monument.

Inscriptions in honour of praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you can sort the inscriptions honoring a living or deceased praetorian prefect, inscriptions carved during or after his prefecture, inscriptions celebrating the prefect(s), inscriptions honouring a prefect affected by damnatio or rehabilitated, along with the reasons behind the dedication and the panegyric formulas.

Awarder of monuments to praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you can sort the inscriptions by awarder: their clients / cities under their administration / city senates (ordo / βουλῆ); provinces (concilia / κοινά); collegia and guilds; individuals; emperors; family members).
Epitaph of a praetorian prefect: by selecting this, you can sort the funerary inscriptions commemorating a specific praetorian prefect.
Inscriptions Identifying a property of a praetorian prefect: by selecting this, you can sort inscriptions mentioning the properties of a specific praetorian prefect.
Inscription containing legal acts sent to praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you can sort the inscriptions featuring imperial constitutions etc. addressed to a prefect.
Inscription containing legal acts issued by praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you can sort the inscriptions featuring edicts or letters issued by the praetorian prefects.

Inscribed monuments made by the praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you can sort the following types of inscriptions: Inscriptions to Augusti/Caesars by a single prefect or by all praetorian prefects, inscriptions where the awardee was a praetorian prefect affected by damnatio (erased) or officially rehabilitated; constructions/restorations of civil, military, religious buildings; other categories of public, private, religious inscriptions.
The praetorian prefecture in inscriptions: by selecting this, you can sort the inscriptions according to information provided in each inscription about the praetorian prefecture, i.e., the office:

list.item: - Inscriptions with the full or partial cursus honorum of the prefect or without cursus honorum;
- Inscriptions recording more than one appointment as praetorian prefect, or the total duration of one, several, or all mandates as prefect;
- Inscriptions recording the current or just completed prefecture only;
- Inscriptions mentioning or not mentioning the regional area of the prefecture;
- Inscriptions recording the number of the prefectures attained by the dignitary without mentioning the regional area of the prefecture;
- Inscriptions recording the number of the prefectures attained by the dignitary mentioning the regional area of the prefecture;
- Inscriptions recording the geographical origin of the prefect.

div.p: The rank of the praetorian prefects: by selecting this, you will get a list of the ranks of the prefect(s), in Latin and Greek, as they appear in the epigraphic text of each inscription.

Latin or Greek titulature of the office: by selecting this, you will get a list of titulatures of the praetorian prefect’s office, in Latin and Greek, as they appear in the epigraphic text of each inscription.
SOURCES

Source mentioned in the commentary: by selecting one of the three options (literary, epigraphic, papyrological) you can get a list of abbreviations for relevant single passages of the corresponding source type quoted in the commentary of each inscription.
